description:
Tree works in a Conservation Area.

Works: 
T1 Silver Birch - Prune to clear property to give up to 1m clearance
T2 Silver Birch - Prune to clear property and cables to give up to 1m clearance
T3,4 and 5 Silver Birch - Prune to clear the southern wall by 1m to allow light perculation between canopy and wall. Crown thin by up to 20% crown volume. Crown lift to 5m above ground level by the removal of sub lateral branches.
T7  Acer - Prune to clear property and cables to give up to 1m clearance
T9 Cherry - dead, remove.
T10 London Plane - Prune to clear property to give up to 5m clearance, crown thin by up to 15% of crown volume 
T13 Holly -  Prune to clear property to give up to 1m clearance
T15 Cherry -  Prune to clear property to give up to 1m clearance
T16 Cherry - Crown reduce to the last previous points of reduction, approx 20% of branch length
T19 Silver Birch - Prune to clear property to give up to 1m clearance
T20 Sycamore - Lift by the removal of sublaterals and epicormic growth to give a clearance of up to 4m above ground level.
T28 Sycamore - Crown reduce by up to 30% of branch length and monitor annually
T30 Ash - Fell
T34 Rowan - sever ivy
T35 Lime - Lift by the removal of sublaterals and epicormic growth to give a clearance of up to 4m above ground level. Remove basal growth.
T36 Lime - Lift by the removal of sublaterals and epicormic growth to give a clearance of up to 4m above ground level. Prune to clear street light to give up to 1.5m clearance
T37 Sycamore -  Prune to clear fence to give up to 1.5m clearance
T42 Ash - Crown reduce to the last previous points of reduction, approx 30% of branch length
T44 Rowan - Prune to clear property to give up to 1m clearance
T46 Rowan - Prune to clear property to give up to 1m clearance
T47 Rowan - Prune to clear property to give up to 1m clearance
T50 Holly - Prune to clear property to give up to 1m clearance
decision_conditions: It has been noted that there has been a gradual decline in tree numbers on Morland Mews and the associated open space. In a conservation area it is expected that replacement trees are planted to compensate for the tree loss to maintain the amenity and environmental benefits that trees provide. If advice is required on species and location for replacement trees, please contact the tree officer for advice.
